I wonder if anyone will pick up https://cctbio.ece.umn.edu/wiki/images/b/bc/Riedel_Bruck_The_Synthesis_of_Cyclic_Combinational_Circuits.pdf / http://www.mriedel.ece.umn.edu/wiki/images/7/7a/Riedel_Cyclic_Combinational_Circuits.pdf now that hardware wins are harder to come by.

I remember asking around about why this work wasn't being picked up circa 2005 and the answer from folks was that there are too many interacting tools that would all have to change for someone to do it for "just" a 5% to 10% win.

On the one hand, 5% to 10% is a much bigger deal than it used to be. But on the other hand, tool complexity has gone way up since then.

Very quick TIL: I figured out how to use VALUES syntax in a CTE in SQLite:

with x(c1, c2, c3) as (
values
('a', 'b', 3),
('b', 'c', 4)
)
select * from x

Handy for if you need to join against some temporary data that you can include in the query itself - or just for writing demonstration queries.

last_post.content:
NASA's Juno spacecraft is performing far beyond its original mission objectives. Launched in 2011, it entered Jupiter’s orbit in July 2016 and was expected to perform 36 science orbits around Jupiter and end the mission in early 2018, with a dive into Jupiter's atmosphere. Instead, it has performed 48 longer-period orbits and will continue its extended mission at least until Sep. 2025.

"Cistercian Numbers" are incredibly cool

It's a rare numeric system designed by 13th century monks

Each number is a based on a single vertical stick, with patterns you draw in all four quadrants off it -- top right, top left, bottom right, bottom left

A single glyph can represent a number from 1 to 9,999

Some #Twitter things that the company didn’t build or invent itself:

• Twitterrific was the first mobile Twitter app

• The word tweet made its first official appearance on Twitterrific

• The hashtag was from Chris Messina

• Advanced Twitter Search was originally Summize

• Twitter bought TweetDeck

• Live stream was from Periscope acquisition

• The official Twitter app was originally Tweetie which they purchased from Loren Brichter

• Mentioning people with an @ was user driven and wasn’t linked to accounts because they didn’t consider conversations to take place on Twitter initially

• Quote tweet was adopted from people copy+pasting tweets and adding RT in front of the copied tweet

• Threads were built to accomodate existing user behavior

Did I miss anything major?

[update 29/1] lots of additions in the replies that I thought should get added here

• Image attachments added after third party services like imageshack/yfrog, and twitpic became super popular.

• Twitterrific was first to officially associate Twitter with a bird

• Retweet was adopted from user behavior (you couldn’t comment or add context using the official retweet so many people kept using RT until Twitter introduced native QT)

• Scheduling, posting across accounts, and team/shared accounts were from Hootsuite

• Popularity of short link services like isgd and bitly lead to tco url masking

Something that people may not have been aware, in my corner of Twitter in those early years, people interpreted RT not as retweet but as reply to. So they weren’t replying by hitting the reply button but by manually quote tweeting and adding RT after their response.

There’s enough confusion over RT so I’m gonna add this example

title: GitHub - asiekierka/almost-of-zzt: (Almost) development backup of ZZT's original source code.

last_post.content:
According to Tim Sweeney, the original ZZT source code was lost in the early 90s: "[... If] I had it, I'd release it, but I lost it in a crash a long time ago."

But they were all of them deceived, for another backup was made.

This is an (almost) unaltered copy of the actual ZZT ~3.0 source code - not decompiled, not reverse-engineered, but preserved for its historical value.

You wouldn't believe me if I told you how many years I spent looking for it, after catching wind of where it might be... For three decades, the ZZT community hoped it would turn up. For two, it thought it was impossible. And yet, here we are.

I'm really happy to have been able to contribute to the ZZT community's preservation efforts for all these years. Thank you. This is probably my magnum opus.

https://github.com/asiekierka/almost-of-zzt

Happy #privacyday, so far I’ve been working on:
- #DSA: limits on targetted advertising in certain domains; ban on dark patterns
- #AIAct: Stopping Biometric mass surveillance, AI profiling such as emotional recognition
- Data Act: Preventing governments from misusing data requests to spy on individuals, preventing companies from forcing you to hand over your personal data to use their IoT products.

title: Big Tech was moving cautiously on AI. Then came ChatGPT.

last_post.content:
For years, tech giants like Google and Facebook have been developing the underlying tech behind tools like ChatGPT and Stable Diffusion--but had been cautious about releasing them due to concerns over safety, bias, and misinfo.

Now, with tech stocks tumbling and ChatGPT hype soaring, insiders say there's growing pressure to stop listening to the ethicists and cassandras and charge ahead despite the risks. title: Earth weighs in at six ronnagrams as new prefixes picked for big and small

last_post.content:
The proposal ends by suggesting what might come next, if needed, and suggests only B remains in English alphabet, giving bundecca and bundecto for 10^33 and 10^-33.

Compound prefixes may be needed beyond that.

Here's an article on it:

"In the unanimous vote, ronna, quetta, ronto and quecto triumphed over some rather less scientific proposals including bronto and hella, which had been gaining ground, if only among computer scientists."

title: Shrinking Economy Airline Seat Sizes Are Dangerous for Passengers, According to an Aviation Expert

last_post.content: The FAA hasn't conducted evacuation testing on planes since the 1990's when seat sizes were far more generous and cabin layouts were very different. We don't have realistic data about how a major incident requiring an evacuation would play out on the planes being flown today. #avgeek https://www.cntraveler.com/story/airline-seat-sizes-safety-risks-op-ed

The proposal (PDF: https://www.bipm.org/documents/20126/28433774/working-document-ID-11391/557541d9-fa11-56fb-7806-759fa2e69c7d) said it was important to add new prefixes for big numbers specifically for data storage (bits, bytes, etc) and they didn't want unofficial names to become de facto adopted.

The little number prefixes were added to keep things balanced.

I've released #humanize 4.5.0!

https://github.com/python-humanize/humanize/releases/tag/4.5.0

Amongst the changes, it includes the exciting new SI metric prefixes!

quetta = Q = 10^30
ronna = R = 10^27
ronto = r = 10^-27
quecto = q = 10^-30

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metric_prefix#List_of_SI_prefixes

These were accepted by the International Bureau of Weights at the 27th General Conference on Weights and Measures in Versailles in November:

title: The Window Trick of Las Vegas Hotels

last_post.content:
Las Vegas hotels use a "window trick", an optical illusion to "shrink" the size of massive buildings and make them look less intimidating.

I compare this style to Hong Kong's "monster building" and other residential buildings.

Disclaimer: these are just my personal opinions and extemporaneous thoughts, there's no need to get upset about them.

https://www.schedium.net/2023/01/the-window-trick-of-las-vegas-hotels.html?m=1

title: My perspective on ChatGPT (and creativity and teaching) – Learning and Technology

last_post.content:
“By design, ChatGPT and LLMs are knowledge free. They’re designed to take a corpus of text and determine for any particular chunk of text what other text probabilistically comes next. This produces text, and as I keep arguing, if the probable answers are correct, then the text is probably correct, but the correctness is not inherent in the model and in fact isn’t a part of the model.”

http://tjkendon.ucalgaryblogs.ca/my-perspective-on-chatgpt-and-creativity-and-teaching/
